briefdescription.para: This is used rather than a bool for high visibility.
This is primarily used in unit testing, so we can verify that each invalid message is invalid for the expected reasons.

detaileddescription.para: Thus we really want a distinct enum value for every codepath leaving the validator functions. Enum values are specified manually for ease of debugging (so you can see the enum value given a printf)

memberdef.name: _dbus_header_field_types
memberdef.initializer: { { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_INVALID, DBUS_TYPE_INVALID }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_PATH, DBUS_TYPE_OBJECT_PATH }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_INTERFACE, DBUS_TYPE_STRING }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_MEMBER, DBUS_TYPE_STRING }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_ERROR_NAME, DBUS_TYPE_STRING }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_REPLY_SERIAL, DBUS_TYPE_UINT32 }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_DESTINATION, DBUS_TYPE_STRING }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_SENDER, DBUS_TYPE_STRING }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_SIGNATURE, DBUS_TYPE_SIGNATURE }, { DBUS_HEADER_FIELD_UNIX_FDS, DBUS_TYPE_UINT32 } }

detaileddescription.para: The given offset must point to an existing string or the wrong length will be deleted and replaced with the new string.

place to store byte after the nul byte of the new value

memberdef.name: _dbus_marshal_read_basic

briefdescription.para: Demarshals a basic-typed value.

detaileddescription.para: The "value" pointer is always the address of a variable of the basic type. So e.g. if the basic type is "double" then the pointer is a double*, and if it's "char*" then the pointer is a "char**".

A value of type DBusBasicValue is guaranteed to be large enough to hold any of the types that may be returned, which is handy if you are trying to do things generically. For example you can pass a DBusBasicValue* in to this function, and then pass the same DBusBasicValue* in to _dbus_marshal_basic_type() in order to move a value from one place to another.

parameterdescription.para: pointer to update with new position, or NULL

Re-initializes a header that was previously initialized and never freed.

detaileddescription.para: After this, to make the header valid you have to call _dbus_header_create().

Frees a header.
Initializes dest with a copy of the given header.

detaileddescription.para: Resets the message serial to 0 on the copy.

briefdescription.para: Fills in the primary fields of the header, so the header is ready for use.

detaileddescription.para: NULL may be specified for some or all of the fields to avoid adding those fields. Some combinations of fields don't make sense, and passing them in will trigger an assertion failure.

memberdef.argsstring: (int max_message_length, DBusValidity *validity, int *byte_order, int *fields_array_len, int *header_len, int *body_len, const DBusString *str, int start, int len)
memberdef.name: _dbus_header_have_message_untrusted

briefdescription.para: Given data long enough to contain the length of the message body and the fields array, check whether the data is long enough to contain the entire message (assuming the claimed lengths are accurate).

detaileddescription.para: Also checks that the lengths are in sanity parameters.

parameterdescription.para: maximum length of a valid message
return location for why the data is invalid if it is
return location for claimed fields array length
return location for claimed header length
return location for claimed body length

simplesect.para: TRUE if the data is long enough for the claimed length, and the lengths were valid

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusHeader *header, DBusValidationMode mode, DBusValidity *validity, int byte_order, int fields_array_len, int header_len, int body_len, const DBusString *str, int start, int len)
memberdef.name: _dbus_header_load

briefdescription.para: Creates a message header from potentially-untrusted data.

detaileddescription.para: The return value is TRUE if there was enough memory and the data was valid. If it returns TRUE, the header will be created. If it returns FALSE and *validity == #DBUS_VALIDITY_UNKNOWN_OOM_ERROR, then there wasn't enough memory. If it returns FALSE and *validity != #DBUS_VALIDITY_UNKNOWN_OOM_ERROR then the data was invalid.

The byte_order, fields_array_len, and body_len args should be from _dbus_header_have_message_untrusted(). Validation performed in _dbus_header_have_message_untrusted() is assumed to have been already done.

parameterdescription.para: length of string to look at

simplesect.para: FALSE if no memory or data was invalid, TRUE otherwise

briefdescription.para: Fills in the correct body length.

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusHeader *header, int field, int type, const void *value)
memberdef.name: _dbus_header_set_field_basic

briefdescription.para: Sets the value of a field with basic type.

detaileddescription.para: If the value is a string value, it isn't allowed to be NULL. If the field doesn't exist, it will be created.

briefdescription.para: Gets the value of a field with basic type.

detaileddescription.para: If the field doesn't exist, returns FALSE, otherwise returns TRUE.

simplesect.para: FALSE if the field doesn't exist

briefdescription.para: Gets the raw marshaled data for a field.

parameterdescription.para: return location for the data string
return location for start of field value

simplesect.para: FALSE if the field doesn't exist

briefdescription.para: Deletes a field, if it exists.
Toggles a message flag bit, turning on the bit if value = TRUE and flipping it off if value = FALSE.
Gets a message flag bit, returning TRUE if the bit is set.

briefdescription.para: Swaps the header into the given order if required.

detaileddescription.para: The signature is read starting at type_pos, and the next type position is stored in the same variable.

parameterdescription.para: an integer position in the type signature (in and out)

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusTypeReader *reader, int byte_order, const DBusString *type_str, int type_pos, const DBusString *value_str, int value_pos)
memberdef.name: _dbus_type_reader_init

briefdescription.para: Initializes a type reader.

parameterdescription.para: the byte order of the block to read
the signature of the block to read

briefdescription.para: Like _dbus_type_reader_init() but the iteration is over the signature, not over values.
Gets the type of the value the reader is currently pointing to; or for a types-only reader gets the type it's currently pointing to.

detaileddescription.para: If the reader is at the end of a block or end of a container such as an array, returns DBUS_TYPE_INVALID.

briefdescription.para: Gets the type of an element of the array the reader is currently pointing to.

detaileddescription.para: It's an error to call this if _dbus_type_reader_get_current_type() doesn't return DBUS_TYPE_ARRAY for this reader.

briefdescription.para: Gets the current position in the value block.
Get the address of the marshaled value in the data being read.

detaileddescription.para: The address may not be aligned; you have to align it to the type of the value you want to read. Most of the demarshal routines do this for you.

parameterdescription.para: the address of the marshaled value

briefdescription.para: Reads a basic-typed value, as with _dbus_marshal_read_basic().
Returns the number of bytes in the array.

simplesect.para: the number of bytes in the array

briefdescription.para: Reads a block of fixed-length basic values, from the current point in an array to the end of the array.

detaileddescription.para: Does not work for arrays of string or container types.
This function returns the array in-place; it does not make a copy, and it does not swap the bytes.
If you ask for DBUS_TYPE_DOUBLE you will get a "const double*" back and the "value" argument should be a "const double**" and so on.

parameterdescription.para: place to return the array values
place to return number of array elements

briefdescription.para: Initialize a new reader pointing to the first type and corresponding value that's a child of the current container.

detaileddescription.para: It's an error to call this if the current type is a non-container.
Note that DBusTypeReader traverses values, not types. So if you have an empty array of array of int, you can't recurse into it. You can only recurse into each element.

parameterdescription.para: a reader to init pointing to the first child

briefdescription.para: Skip to the next value on this "level".

detaileddescription.para: e.g. the next field in a struct, the next value in an array. Returns FALSE at the end of the current container.

simplesect.para: FALSE if nothing more to read at or below this level

briefdescription.para: Check whether there's another value on this "level".

detaileddescription.para: e.g. the next field in a struct, the next value in an array. Returns FALSE at the end of the current container.
You probably don't want to use this; it makes for an awkward for/while loop. A nicer one is "while ((current_type = get_current_type()) != INVALID)"

simplesect.para: FALSE if nothing more to read at or below this level

briefdescription.para: Gets the string and range of said string containing the signature of the current value.

detaileddescription.para: Essentially a more complete version of _dbus_type_reader_get_current_type() (returns the full type rather than only the outside of the onion).

Note though that the first byte in a struct signature is DBUS_STRUCT_BEGIN_CHAR while the current type will be DBUS_TYPE_STRUCT so it isn't true that the first byte of the signature is always the same as the current type. Another difference is that this function will still return a signature when inside an empty array; say you recurse into empty array of int32, the signature is "i" but the current type will always be DBUS_TYPE_INVALID since there are no elements to be currently pointing to.

parameterdescription.para: place to return the string with the type in it
place to return start of the type
place to return the length of the type

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusTypeReader *reader, int current_type, const void *value, const DBusTypeReader *realign_root)
memberdef.name: reader_set_basic_variable_length

briefdescription.para: Sets a new value for the basic type value pointed to by the reader, leaving the reader valid to continue reading.

detaileddescription.para: Any other readers will be invalidated if you set a variable-length type such as a string.

The provided realign_root is the reader to start from when realigning the data that follows the newly-set value. The reader parameter must point to a value below the realign_root parameter. If the type being set is fixed-length, then realign_root may be NULL. Only values reachable from realign_root will be realigned, so if your string contains other values you will need to deal with those somehow yourself. It is OK if realign_root is the same reader as the reader parameter, though if you aren't setting the root it may not be such a good idea.

xrefdescription.para: DBusTypeReader currently takes "const" versions of the type and value strings, and this function modifies those strings by casting away the const, which is of course bad if we want to get picky. (To be truly clean you'd have an object which contained the type and value strings and set_basic would be a method on that object... this would also make DBusTypeReader the same thing as DBusTypeMark. But since DBusMessage is effectively that object for D-Bus it doesn't seem worth creating some random object.)
optimize this by only rewriting until the old and new values are at the same alignment. Frequently this should result in only replacing the value that's immediately at hand.

parameterdescription.para: reader indicating where to set a new value
address of the value to set

briefdescription.para: Recursively deletes any value pointed to by the reader, leaving the reader valid to continue reading.

detaileddescription.para: Any other readers will be invalidated.
The provided realign_root is the reader to start from when realigning the data that follows the newly-set value. See _dbus_type_reader_set_basic() for more details on the realign_root paramter.

xrefdescription.para: for now this does not delete the typecodes associated with the value, so this function should only be used for array elements.

parameterdescription.para: reader indicating where to delete a value

briefdescription.para: Compares two readers, which must be iterating over the same value data.

detaileddescription.para: Returns TRUE if the first parameter is further along than the second parameter.

simplesect.para: whether lhs is greater than rhs

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusTypeWriter *writer, int byte_order, DBusString *type_str, int type_pos, DBusString *value_str, int value_pos)
memberdef.name: _dbus_type_writer_init

briefdescription.para: Initialize a write iterator, which is used to write out values in serialized D-Bus format.

detaileddescription.para: The type_pos passed in is expected to be inside an already-valid, though potentially empty, type signature. This means that the byte after type_pos must be either DBUS_TYPE_INVALID (aka nul) or some other valid type. DBusTypeWriter won't enforce that the signature is already valid (you can append the nul byte at the end if you like), but just be aware that you need the nul byte eventually and DBusTypeWriter isn't going to write it for you.

parameterdescription.para: the byte order to marshal into
the string to write typecodes into
the string to write values into

briefdescription.para: Initialize a write iterator, with the signature to be provided later.

parameterdescription.para: the byte order to marshal into
the string to write values into

briefdescription.para: Adds type string to the writer, if it had none.
Removes type string from the writer.

detaileddescription.para: The writer will check what you write vs. this existing signature.

detaileddescription.para: those that are both dbus_type_is_fixed() and _dbus_type_is_basic(). The block must be written inside an array.
The value parameter should be the address of said array of values, so e.g. if it's an array of double, pass in "const double**"

number of elements in the array

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusTypeWriter *writer, DBusTypeReader *reader, const DBusTypeReader *start_after, int start_after_new_pos, int start_after_new_len, DBusList **fixups, dbus_bool_t inside_start_after)
memberdef.name: writer_write_reader_helper

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusTypeWriter *writer, DBusTypeReader *reader, const DBusTypeReader *start_after, int start_after_new_pos, int start_after_new_len, DBusList **fixups)
memberdef.name: _dbus_type_writer_write_reader_partial

briefdescription.para: Iterate through all values in the given reader, writing a copy of each value to the writer.

detaileddescription.para: The reader will be moved forward to its end position.

If a reader start_after is provided, it should be a reader for the same data as the reader to be written. Only values occurring after the value pointed to by start_after will be written to the writer.

If start_after is provided, then the copy of the reader will be partial. This means that array lengths will not have been copied. The assumption is that you wrote a new version of the value at start_after to the writer. You have to pass in the start position and length of the new value. (If you are deleting the value at start_after, pass in 0 for the length.)

If the fixups parameter is non-NULL, then any array length that was read but not written due to start_after will be provided as a DBusArrayLenFixup. The fixup contains the position of the array length in the source data, and the correct array length assuming you combine the source data before start_after with the written data at start_after and beyond.

parameterdescription.para: NULL or a reader showing where to start
the position of start_after equivalent in the target data
the length of start_after equivalent in the target data
list to append DBusArrayLenFixup if the write was partial

briefdescription.para: Iterate through all values in the given reader, writing a copy of each value to the writer.

detaileddescription.para: The reader will be moved forward to its end position.

briefdescription.para: If disabled, a writer can still be iterated forward and recursed/unrecursed but won't write any values.

detaileddescription.para: Types will still be written unless the writer is a "values only" writer, because the writer needs access to a valid signature to be able to iterate.

parameterdescription.para: TRUE if values should be written

briefdescription.para: Verifies that the range of type_str from type_pos to type_end is a valid signature.

detaileddescription.para: If this function returns TRUE, it will be safe to iterate over the signature with a types-only DBusTypeReader. The range passed in should NOT include the terminating nul/DBUS_TYPE_INVALID.

simplesect.para: #DBUS_VALID if valid, reason why invalid otherwise

memberdef.argsstring: (DBusTypeReader *reader, int byte_order, dbus_bool_t walk_reader_to_end, int total_depth, const unsigned char *p, const unsigned char *end, const unsigned char **new_p)
memberdef.name: validate_body_helper

memberdef.argsstring: (const DBusString *expected_signature, int expected_signature_start, int byte_order, int *bytes_remaining, const DBusString *value_str, int value_pos, int len)
memberdef.name: _dbus_validate_body_with_reason

briefdescription.para: Verifies that the range of value_str from value_pos to value_end is a legitimate value of type expected_signature.

detaileddescription.para: If this function returns TRUE, it will be safe to iterate over the values with DBusTypeReader. The signature is assumed to be already valid.
If bytes_remaining is not NULL, then leftover bytes will be stored there and #DBUS_VALID returned. If it is NULL, then #DBUS_INVALID_TOO_MUCH_DATA will be returned if bytes are left over.

parameterdescription.para: the expected types in the value_str
where in expected_signature is the signature

simplesect.para: #DBUS_VALID if valid, reason why invalid otherwise

briefdescription.para: Checks that the given range of the string is a valid object path name in the D-Bus protocol.

detaileddescription.para: Part of the validation ensures that the object path contains only ASCII.

xrefdescription.para: this is inconsistent with most of DBusString in that it allows a start,len range that extends past the string end.
change spec to disallow more things, such as spaces in the path name

simplesect.para: TRUE if the byte range exists and is a valid name

briefdescription.para: Checks that the given range of the string is a valid interface name in the D-Bus protocol.

detaileddescription.para: This includes a length restriction and an ASCII subset, see the specification.

xrefdescription.para: this is inconsistent with most of DBusString in that it allows a start,len range that extends past the string end.

simplesect.para: TRUE if the byte range exists and is a valid name

briefdescription.para: Checks that the given range of the string is a valid member name in the D-Bus protocol.

detaileddescription.para: This includes a length restriction, etc., see the specification.

xrefdescription.para: this is inconsistent with most of DBusString in that it allows a start,len range that extends past the string end.

simplesect.para: TRUE if the byte range exists and is a valid name

briefdescription.para: Checks that the given range of the string is a valid error name in the D-Bus protocol.

detaileddescription.para: This includes a length restriction, etc., see the specification.

xrefdescription.para: this is inconsistent with most of DBusString in that it allows a start,len range that extends past the string end.

simplesect.para: TRUE if the byte range exists and is a valid name

briefdescription.para: Checks that the given range of the string is a valid bus name in the D-Bus protocol.

detaileddescription.para: This includes a length restriction, etc., see the specification.

xrefdescription.para: this is inconsistent with most of DBusString in that it allows a start,len range that extends past the string end.

simplesect.para: TRUE if the byte range exists and is a valid name

briefdescription.para: Checks that the given range of the string is a valid message type signature in the D-Bus protocol.

xrefdescription.para: this is inconsistent with most of DBusString in that it allows a start,len range that extends past the string end.

simplesect.para: TRUE if the byte range exists and is a valid signature

A name check is used in _dbus_return_if_fail(), it's not suitable for validating untrusted data.

detaileddescription.para: use _dbus_validate_whatever for that.

memberdef.name: DEFINE_DBUS_NAME_CHECK
memberdef.initializer: dbus_bool_t \ _dbus_check_is_valid_##what (const char *name) \ { \ DBusString str; \ \ if (name == NULL) \ return FALSE; \ \ _dbus_string_init_const (&str, name); \ return _dbus_validate_##what (&str, 0, \ _dbus_string_get_length (&str)); \ }

briefdescription.para: Define a name check to be used in _dbus_return_if_fail() statements.
functions to marshal/unmarshal data from the wire

detaileddescription.para: Types and functions related to converting primitive data types from wire format to native machine format, and vice versa.
A signature is just a string with multiple types one after the other. for example a type is "i" or "(ii)", a signature is "i(ii)" where i is int and (ii) is struct { int; int; }
